p: A linear model testing copepod body mass and temperature category as predictors of predation efficiency explained 14.0% of the variance in predation efficiency ( Table 2). For each 0.1 mg increase in copepod body mass, the predation efficiency increased by approximately 3.4 percentage points (p-value = 0.0042), when controlling for differences in temperature ( Table 2, Fig 3B). Interactions between body mass and temperature were not significant (Mass x Temperature 20, p-value = 0.611; Mass x Temperature 25, p-value = 0.565).
